questions.text: It is shoulder dystocia when the anterior shoulder is delivered after what time of head delivery?
questions.explanation:
Maternal Complications

Neonatal Complications
  • Soft tissue injuries: Lacerations of the bladder, urethra, vagina, anal sphincter, or rectum
  • Nerve injury: Lateral femoral cutaneous neuropathy
  • Postpartum hemorrhage
  • Pelvic injury: Symphyseal separation
  • Uterine rupture
  • Fetal death
  • Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE)
  • Fractures: Clavicle or humerus
  • Neurologic injuries:
    • Brachial plexus injury
    • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Facial nerve injury
    • Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis)

questions.text: Which of the following is the next appropriate step in management after the failure of the McRobert maneuver in a case of shoulder dystocia?

A 28-year-old G2P1 presents in active labor at 39 weeks gestation. On examination, the fetus is in occiput posterior (OP) position with reassuring fetal heart tones. She had a previous uncomplicated vaginal delivery. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Proceed with normal vaginal delivery
questions.explanation:
Part

Position

Engaging diameter

Mechanism of labor

VERTEX

(Flexed)

Occipito-anterior

Suboccipito-bregmatic (9.5 cm)

Vaginal delivery (head born by extension)

Occipito-posterior

Sub-occipitofrontal (10 cm) or Occipitofrontal (11.5 cm)
  • Anterior 3/8" rotation → OA → Vaginal delivery
  • Anterior 1/8" rotation → OT → manual rotation - forceps ext, LSCS in case of DTA
  • Posterior 1/8" rotation → DOP → Face to pubis delivery

BROW

(deflexed)

 

Mento-vertical (14cm)

No mechanism → LSCS

FACE

(extended)

Mento-anterior

Sub-mento-bregmatic (9.5 cm)

Vaginal delivery (head delivers by flexion)

Mento-posterior

Sterno-bregmatic (17.5 cm)
  • Anterior 3/8" rotation → MA → Vaginal delivery
  • Anterior 1/8" rotation → MT → LSCS
  • Posterior 1/8" rotation → MP → LSCS

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1 woman at 41 weeks gestation is in active labor. She has a history of gestational diabetes and her previous baby weighed 4.2 kg. During delivery, the fetal head delivers normally, but afterward, despite gentle traction, the shoulders fail to deliver. During delivery, the head is delivered, but the shoulders become stuck. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old G1P0 woman has been pushing for 2 hours with minimal progression. The obstetrician is considering outlet forceps assistance. On examination, the fetal head is visible at the vaginal opening. Outlet forceps are applied at which station?
questions.explanation:
Procedure

Criteria

Outlet forceps
  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Head is OA or OP or
  • Head is right or left OA or OP position but rotation ≤45 degrees

Low forceps (2 types)
  • Fetal station is ≥+2 cm but not on the pelvic floor, and:
  • (a) Rotation ≤45 degrees is required or
  • (b) Rotation >45 degrees is required

Midforceps
  • Fetal station is between 0 and +2 cm

Prerequisites
  • Engaged head
  • Vertex presentation
  • Known fetal head position
  • CPD not suspected
  • Fetal weight estimated
  • Experienced operator
  • Ruptured membranes
  • Completely dilated cervix
  • Adequate anesthesia
  • Emptied maternal bladder
  • No fetal coagulopathy
  • No fetal demineralization disorder
  • Informed consent completed
  • Willingness to abandon OVD

CPD = cephalopelvic disproportion; OA = occiput anterior; OP = occiput posterior; OVD = operative vaginal delivery.

questions.text: In a 35-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation, which of the following conditions is oxytocin contraindicated for?

options.label: B
options.text: Induction of labor in post-term pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Augmentation of labor in case of slow progress

options.label: D
options.text: Preterm labor with cervical dilation of 3 cm

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?

options.label: A
options.text: 4 contractions in 20 minutes and 8 contractions in 60 minutes with changes in the cervix.

options.label: B
options.text: Cervical dilatation > 2 cm. More than 80 percent effaced cervix. Cervix posterior in position.

questions.explanation:
Parameter

Score 0

Score 1

Score 2

Score 3

Cervical Dilation

Closed or ≤1 cm

2-3 cm

4-5 cm

≥6 cm

Cervical Effacement

0-30%

40-50%

60-70%

≥80%

Fetal Station

-3 (high)

-2 (presenting part at ischial spines)

-1 to 0 (at the level of the ischial spines)

+1 to +2 (below the ischial spines)

Cervical Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

Very soft

Cervical Position

Posterior

Mid-position

Anterior

Very anterior

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score.
questions.explanation:
Criteria

0 Points

1 Point

2 Points

3 Points

Dilation (cm)

Closed

1-2

3-4

≥5

Cervical length

4 cm

2-4 cm

1-2 cm

<1cm

Station

-3

-2

-1, 0

+1, +2

Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

 

Position

Posterior

Mid position

Anterior

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, on examination, was found to have infra-umbilical flattening. The fetal heart sounds were heard over the lateral side. What could be the fetal presentation/ position?
During an examination of a woman in labor, a midwife observes a prolapsed cord. What is the immediate next step in managing this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina

options.label: B
options.text: Inform the doctor and shift to OT

options.label: D
options.text: Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.correct_answer: C. Put her in Trendelenberg position

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of a woman in labour with a planned vaginal breech delivery is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

options.label: B
options.text: Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency cesarean delivery is available

options.label: C
options.text: Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labour

options.label: D
options.text: Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.correct_answer: A. Breech identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Lack of experience of doctor
  • ↳ Patient's preference for a cesarean delivery
  • ↳ History of perinatal death or neonatal birth injury
  • ↳ Fetal characteristics observed via sonography:
  • ↳ Fetal characteristics observed via sonography:
  • ↳ Large fetal size: >3800-4000 g Severe intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), with a term fetal weight <2500-2800 g Oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid) Fetal anomalies that would make vaginal delivery unsafe Incomplete breech presentation Hyperextended fetal neck Preterm fetus that is otherwise healthy but either in active labor or with other indications for delivery
  • ↳ Large fetal size: >3800-4000 g
  • ↳ Severe intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), with a term fetal weight <2500-2800 g
  • ↳ Oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid)
  • ↳ Fetal anomalies that would make vaginal delivery unsafe
  • ↳ Incomplete breech presentation
  • ↳ Hyperextended fetal neck
  • ↳ Preterm fetus that is otherwise healthy but either in active labor or with other indications for delivery
  • ↳ Maternal Factors:
  • ↳ Maternal Factors:
  • ↳ Pelvic contraction or an unfavorable pelvic shape, either clinically or determined through pelvimetry History of a prior cesarean delivery
  • ↳ Pelvic contraction or an unfavorable pelvic shape, either clinically or determined through pelvimetry
  • ↳ History of a prior cesarean delivery

questions.text: At what point of cervical dilatation should a nursing assistant in the obstetric care unit begin plotting a paragraph to track labor progress?

Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged when the obstetrician observes that the episiotomy performed during a successful delivery has extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body?
Identify the type of pelvis shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Gynecoid

(Option A)

Android

(Option C)

Anthropoid

Platypelloid

(Option D)

Shape

Round or slightly oval

Heart-shaped

Oval (anteroposterior)

Flattened oval (transverse)

Prevalence

Most common (~50%)

~20%

~25%

Rare (~5%)

Description
  • Transversely oval pelvic inlet
  • Broad, shallow sacrum
  • Blunt, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Wide subpubic angle (>90°)
  • Triangular or heart-shaped pelvic inlet
  • Flat, forward-inclined sacrum
  • Prominent, closely spaced ischial spines
  • Narrow subpubic angle (<70°)
  • Oval pelvic inlet (anteroposterior > transverse)
  • Long, narrow sacrum
  • Less prominent, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Narrow subpubic angle (~70°)
  • Wide, flat pelvic inlet (transverse > anteroposterior)
  • Short, flat sacrum
  • Blunt, widely spaced ischial spines
  • Wide subpubic angle (>90°)

Obstetric Significance
  • Ideal for vaginal delivery due to spacious cavity and optimal dimensions
  • Increased risk of obstructed labor
  • Associated with deep transverse arrest
  • Favors occipito-posterior fetal positions
  • Vaginal delivery usually possible
  • Delayed engagement of the fetal head
  • Higher likelihood of cesarean delivery

questions.text: A 23-year-old G3 P1L1 A1 at 37 weeks of gestation with a previous history of emergency caesarean section and dilatation and curettage presents to the ER with labor pains. During abdominal examination, it was difficult to palpate fetal parts. Per vaginal examination revealed a 5 cm dilated cervix, and her vitals were: BP-80/60 mmHg, RR – 20/min, HR – 106/min, SpO2 – 97% on room air. CTG showed a non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.
  • Blood collects within the uterus, causing increased pressure and pain without visible bleeding.

Mixed

  • Involves both concealed and revealed bleeding.
  • There is both internal and external bleeding, with some blood exiting through the vagina and some collecting behind the placenta.

Grade

Maternal findings

Fetal findings

0
  • Clinical features may be absent.
  • The diagnosis is made after inspection of the placenta following delivery.

1

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness ±)

Fetal heart sounds are normal

2

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain
(Uterine tenderness always +)

Fetal distress

3

Bleeding PV + Abdominal pain (marked uterine tenderness) + Shock ± Coagulopathy

Fetal death

 

Placenta previa

Abruptio placentae

Clinical features

Nature of bleeding

Painless, causeless, and recurrent.

Painful, often attributed to Pre-eclampsia or trauma, and continuous.

Character of blood

Bleeding is always revealed.

Revealed, concealed, or usually mixed.

General condition & anaemia

Proportionate to visible blood loss.

Out of proportion to the visible blood loss in the concealed or mixed variety.

Features of eclampsia

Not relevant.

Present in one-third of the cases.

Abdominal examination

Height of the uterus

Proportionate height to the gestational age.

It may be disproportionately enlarged in concealed type.

The feel of the uterus

Soft and relaxed.

It may be tense, tender, and rigid.

Malpresentation

Common (the head is high floating).

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Fetal heart sounds

Usually present.

Usually absent, especially in the concealed type.

USG, MRI

Placenta in the lower segment.

Placenta in the upper segment.

Vaginal examination

The placenta is felt on the lower segment (not to be done in a suspected case).

The placenta is not felt on the lower segment. Blood clots should not be confused with placenta.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1L1 presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum in labor, and loss of fetal movements. She occasionally smokes but does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, her pulse rate is 80 bpm, BP is 150/90 mmHg, and her abdomen is tense on palpation. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Revealed

  • Most common type, where the bleeding from the placental detachment is visible and exits through the vagina.
  • This is often associated with vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain.

Concealed

  • Bleeding is hidden behind the placenta and is not visible externally.

Fetal findings

1

Fetal heart sounds are normal

Fetal distress

3

Fetal death

Abruptio placentae

Unrelated, the head may be engaged.

Usually present.
